text: The basic tenet of Attachment Theory is that a person's emotional attachments influence the way in which he deals with problematic situations and, moreover, that the way in which he deals with problematic situations influences his relations to others. Attachment Theory is not a single theory but a cluster of theories all based on this tenet.

It is a matter of common knowledge that people who have healthy and secure attachments, particularly in early life, are psychologically healthier than people who do not. This knowledge seems to be embodied in parental instincts, given that parents, especially mothers, are naturally inclined to bond with their children, especially when they are young and vulnerable.

Freud's position was that a psychologically healthy adult is someone whose parents loved him but did not spoil him, it being the mother's job to provide love and the father's job to provide discipline. A mother's love leads to self-love, according to Freud, and a father's discipline leads to self-discipline, with a person's success as an adult depending on his having a healthy combination of self-love and self-discipline.

John Bowlby was a psychoanalyst who studied the effects of separating children from caregivers. Bowlby observed that the children who reacted the most violently to separation from caregivers were the first to be given substitute-caregivers and were therefore the most likely to survive. On this basis, Bowlby hypothesized that these extreme behaviors were survival mechanisms that were reinforced by natural selection.

Bowlby coined the term 'attachment behavioral system' (ABS) to refer to the behaviors and attitudes that determine how a given person forms relationships and also deals with abandonment. Bowlby held that a person's ABS is largely determined by the nature of his early-life relationships with caregivers. Bowlby also held that in order to become a healthy adult, a child needed to have at least one stable attachment with a caregiver.
Research based on Bowlby's work led to the hypothesis that there are four basic attachment patterns in infants: Secure, Anxious-ambivalent, Anxious-avoidant, and Disorganized.

Infants with secure attachments to their caregivers are happy and self-confident while in the presence of the caregiver; they boldly explore the room and initiate relations with others. When the caregiver leaves, they are distressed but functional, and they are unambiguously happy when she returns. Such infants have nurturing and dependable caregivers.

Infants with anxious-ambivalent attachments are cautious and concerned; they do not boldly explore their surroundings. When the caregiver is present, they are worried that the caregiver will soon leave. They are distressed when the caregiver leaves, but do not greet the caregiver when she returns. Such infants have emotionally withdrawn and unreliable caregivers.

Infants with anxious-avoidant attachments are not distressed when the caregiver leaves, and they avoid the caregiver when she returns. They tend to focus on toys and other purely physical aspects of their environment and have a diminished interest in other people. Such infants have abusive caregivers.

Infants with disorganized attachments respond with fear to returning caregivers. They may actively avoid the caregiver; they may pretend to be unconscious; they may rise up defiantly; or they cycle through all of these behaviors. Such infants have extremely abusive or highly unreliable caregivers.
Children with secure attachments have positive relations with others. They see others as helpful and that is how others regard them. They do not hesitate to ask others for help but are not clingy.

Children with anxious-ambivalent attachments are insecure. They cling to their primary caregivers and avoid their peers. Children with anxious-avoidant attachments have trouble dealing with stress and are reluctant to enlist the help of others. They tend to develop antisocial behavior patterns, such as lying and bullying, and they tend to self-isolate.

Children with disorganized attachments may either bully others or isolate themselves from others. Such children are extremely reluctant to ask others for help, and they tend to be disruptive and hard to manage.

Adults with secure attachments tend to be happy with their relationships. They enjoy the company of their friends and partners but are not clingy. They are not reluctant to ask for help but are not needy.

Adults with anxious-ambivalent attachments are clingy and desperate. They feel incomplete unless in a relationship. But when in a relationship, they alienate their partners by being jealous and emotionally demanding.

Adults with anxious-avoidant attachments are loners who regard interpersonal relationships as encumbrances. They deal with emotional conflicts with others by withdrawing. They value independence and focus their energy on developing themselves.
Adults with disorganized attachments alternate between clinging to others and withdrawing from others. They tend to have unpredictable mood swings and have difficulty forming lasting relationships.

Attachment insecurities (of both the anxious and avoidant varieties) are associated with depression, clinically significant anxiety, obsessive-compulsive disorder, post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), suicidal tendencies, and eating disorders. OCD, PTSD, and eating disorders all involve fear- or trauma-driven self-isolation.

The obsessive-compulsive is the quintessential loner, hiding not just from the world but from his own emotions, especially his own rage, by barricading himself behind irrational, and therefore fantasy-based, obsessions and compulsions. Compulsive eaters, as well as compulsive non-eaters, are engaged in a similar form of escapism. Those afflicted by PTSD have suffered extreme trauma and have shut themselves off from the world as a way of coping.

Anxious attachment is associated with dependent, histrionic, and borderline disorders, whereas avoidant attachment is associated with schizoid and avoidant disorders. Schizoid and other psychotic disorders involve a scrambling of the subject's very grasp of reality: not only are his emotions out of alignment with reality; his grasp of reality itself has been undermined.

The early-life attachments of those with schizoid disorders were negative, as opposed to ambiguous, disposing them to flee from reality in the most radical way possible. By contrast, those with histrionic, borderline, and dependent disorders have a fundamentally non-delusive grasp of reality, but their emotions are not appropriate to the reality thereby made available to them.

Psychopaths use others; they do not have relationships with them, except of a purely pragmatic kind. A 'psychopath' is defined as someone who lacks conscience and whose behavior therefore consistently embodies a callous disregard for others, a high degree of manipulativeness and deceitfulness, and in some cases a high degree of impulsivity, often leading to reckless behavior, including drug addiction and promiscuity.

Psychopaths are likely to have had attachments of the disorganized variety to caregivers. Although there is some evidence that some people are 'genetic' psychopaths, most psychopaths were treated either coldly or cruelly by key caregivers in early life, their attachments to said caregivers strongly tending to be of the disorganized variety.

Inadequate early-life relationships, especially with caregivers, adversely affect mental health and make it difficult to maintain healthy relationships. Anxious-ambivalent early-life attachments are dispositive of neurosis. Anxious-avoidant early-life attachments are dispositive of psychosis. Disorganized early-life attachments are dispositive of psychopathy.

The neurotic tends to be distrustful of others and ambivalent towards actual and prospective partners, making it difficult for him to form and maintain healthy relationships. The psychotic's grasp of external reality is damaged, making it hard for the psychotic to engage any aspect of the external world, leading to wholesale disengagement from it. The psychopath cannot have meaningful relations with others and does not wish to have such relations.

Psychopaths do not benefit from psychotherapy and they cannot have meaningful relations with others. But neurotics and psychotics can benefit from therapy, and they can have meaningful relations with others.

Good adult relationships are not the solution to the problems caused by bad early-life relationships. Good adult relationships are consequences of solutions to the problems caused by bad early life relationships. If Smith has OCD in consequence of his having insecure early life attachments, the problem that Smith must solve is that he has OCD. As long as Smith has OCD, it will dramatically decrease his ability to initiate positive relationships or maintain them.

As long as a person is seriously mentally ill, his ability to establish or maintain healthy relationships is seriously compromised. Indeed, people with mental illnesses tend to form relationships that validate their symptoms, rather than alleviating them. People with borderline personality disorder, for example, are likely to seek romantic partners who are likely to abandon them and who are therefore likely to reinforce their fears of abandonment.

When a borderline finds a partner who will not abandon her, she often unconsciously manipulates him into doing so. Unless mental issues are addressed on their own terms, unhealthy relationships are likely and healthy ones are unlikely.

The very first healthy relationship that a therapist should help his patient have is with himself. The patient-therapist relationship must be secure if the therapist is to help the patient. No matter how insightful the therapist is, he cannot help the patient except by way of a secure relationship with him. A secure patient-therapist relationship will by itself do more in the way of helping the patient have healthy relationships than any amount of intellectual insight on the therapist's part possibly could.

When a therapist has been able to help patients, it was not by helping them get what they wanted; it was by helping them use their judgment. Whenever a patient insisted that she needed something specific, the patient never benefited from efforts to help her find it. When therapists give patients what they want, they are enabling them and making their problems worse. When therapists give patients what they need, they are actually helping them.

What patients need is always to develop their ability to make informed decisions. It is not always within a therapist's power to eliminate symptoms or to gratify desires, but it is always within a therapist's power to help the patient make rational decisions. Patients who develop good judgment improve, and those who lack it don't. Therapists are therefore under a categorical obligation to help their patients learn how to be rational and autonomous.
